at ocw.mit.edu.

PROFESSOR: Edgerton's Boomer
illustrates the induction

of a current in a
conductor subjected

to a time-varying magnetic
field and the associated
magnetic forces.

It illustrates the interplay
between the laws of Faraday,

Ampere, and Ohm that determines
the distribution, duration,

and magnitude of
currents in conductors

under magneto
quasistatic conditions.

The time-varying magnetic field
will be produced by a current

through the windings
of this coil.

To produce this
current, we'll first

charge this capacitor
to 4 kilovolts

and then discharge the
capacitor through the coil
by closing this switch.
This is the coil.

The winding wire
circulates like so

and is connected to the
capacitors in this cabinet
by these leads.

When the high-voltage
power supply in the cabinet
is turned on,
[MACHINE WHIRRING]

The capacitor is
charged to 4 kilovolts.

The switch then connects
the capacitor to the coil.

It's closed when this
button is pushed.
[BUTTON CLICKING]

The switch consists of a spark
gap, which we just heard.

We can see it if
we open this panel.

The switch is closed by
a spark across this gap.

That spark is activated
by applying a voltage

to this electrode to make a
smaller electrical breakdown
in the gap.

Just once, we'll bypass
the safety interlock

that ordinarily disconnects
the circuit when
the panel is opened.

Then when we push the
button, we can not only

hear the spark discharge
the close of the switch

but see the associated
flash as well.
Maybe we can do it once more.

Given the initial capacitor
of voltage or 4 kilovolts

and that the coil
has 50 turns, we

can use basic principles to
estimate the winding current

and, hence, the magnetic field
intensity produced by the coil.

First, we use Ampere's integral
law to relate the current
to the field.

The line contour encloses
the current in the coil.

Ampere's integral law
applied to this contour C.

Given that the
contour has a radius

equal to the average radius
of the coil winding, a,

the contour integral
is approximated

by the circumference,
2 pi a, multiplied

by the average magnetic
field intensity.

The current passing through
the enclosed surface

is the number of turns, n
sub 1, times the current.

So we can solve for the average
magnetic field intensity.

To use this expression, we need
to know the coil current i sub

If the resistive
loss of the circuit

is small compared to the
inductive and capacitive energy

storage, this current
is a damped oscillation.

In that case, after a
quarter of one oscillation,

all of the energy initially
stored in the capacitor

essentially ends up
stored in the inductor.

The peak energy in the capacitor
is 1/2 the capacitance C

times the square of
the initial voltage.

The peak energy in the
coil a quarter of a cycle

later is 1/2 its inductance
times the peak current squared.

So the peak coil current
is proportional to
the initial capacitor voltage.

To use this expression, we must
estimate the coil inductance.

Remember, Ampere's
law was used to find

this average magnetic
field intensity.

The average flux linked by
all the turns of the coil

is the number of turns times
the average coil area multiplied
by this flux density.

If we use our approximate
field intensity

to evaluate this flux, we see
that it is proportional to i1.

The coefficient is the
desired coil inductance.

For our coil, a is on the
order of 7 centimeters.
There are about 50 turns.

So the coil inductance is
about 1/10 of a millihenry.

In turn, we can now approximate
the peak coil current.

The capacitance
is 16 microfarads.

So for an initial
voltage of 4 kilovolts,

the peak coil current
is about 1,600 amperes.

From this current, it
follows from Ampere's law

that the peak magnetic field
intensity is 1.8 times 10
to the 5th amps per meter.

In free space, the
peak flux density

is, therefore, 0.23
Tesla, about 2,300 Gauss.

The energy oscillates
back and forth

between the capacitor
and the inductor.

Provided that the circuit
resistance is not too large,

this is the frequency
of the oscillation.

Once again, using the
inductance of 1/10 millihenry,

the capacitance
of 16 microfarads,

we estimate the frequency
to be about 4 kilohertz.

Before we go on, let's
see how well we've
approximated the current field.

This current probe will link
one of the wires connected
to the coil.

We display the coil current
on the lower scope trace.

The voltage induced at the
terminals of this coil,

by the time-varying
magnetic flux density,

will be used to deduce B.
This voltage will be displayed
as the upper scope trace.

Here are the responses to the
discharge of the capacitor.

The time axis is 2/10 of a
millisecond per division.

So the period of the oscillation
is about 1/3 of a millisecond.

The oscillation frequency
is roughly the predicted 4
kilohertz.

The duration of the lower
trace current and, hence,

of the field is on the
order of 1 millisecond.

The peak in the current
on the lower trace
is about one division.

There are 1,000
amps per division,

so the peak current
is about 1,000 amps.

This is in the range of the
estimated value of 1,600 amps.

Remember, we've not
accounted for losses
in the spark gap and the coil.

Finally, the voltage
of our induction loop,

the upper trace, is
related to the coil area
and turns by Faraday's law.

The coil voltage is
the rate of change

of the flux, the
product of its area,

its turns, and the
magnetic flux density.

We approximate the
derivative by omega.

So this is B. There
are 200 turns.

The area is 2.4 times 10 to
the minus 4 meters squared.

The estimated frequency
is 4 kilohertz,

and the peak voltage
is 500 volts.

We conclude that near
the center of the coil,

the peak magnetic flux density
is 0.4 Tesla, 4,000 Gauss.

Our estimate of
the space average

for this peak value of the
flux density was 2,300 Gauss--
somewhat less, as it should be.

Now, suppose that
a conducting disk
is placed just above the coil.

What's the current
induced in the disk?

To obtain a rough
approximation, we

begin by applying Faraday's
integral law to this contour.

It encloses the surface S
lying in the plane of the disk.

The line integral of the
azimuthal electric field

is the product of the
average circumference

and that electric
field intensity.

It's equal to the time rate
of change of the net flux

through the enclosed
area, pi a squared.

The current density
circulating in the disk

follows from this
field and Ohm's law.
The disk could represent a hand.

In that case, the
experiment can literally

give a feel for the
consequence of subjecting

a conductor to a
time-varying magnetic field.

If the disk represents a
hand, what current density
would be felt?

Here's our estimated
current density.

For flush, the conductivity
is on the order
of 1 siemen per meter.

Here's the permeability of
free space and the average coil
radius.

The angular frequency, roughly
2 pi times 4 kilohertz.

This is our calculated
average field intensity.

So the current density
is approximately 200 amps
per square meter.

Because a square centimeter is
typical of the cross-sectional

area through a hand,
we have a better feel

for this number
expressed as 20 milliamps
per square centimeter.

This is more than enough
to give a good shock.

Magnetic field created by
the coil is non-uniform.
Far away, that of a dipole.

So we can discern what we're
getting into by feeling
the induced current in stages.

The sensation is of a
short duration twinge,

much as would be expected
for a pulse that lasts
one millisecond.

I've been given to understand
that Professor Zahn is not

going to try it with his
hand lower than this.

So that you can see
evidence of the field

that you can't feel firsthand,
let's replace his hand
by this while loop.

The wire is open at this point,
with the ends barely touching.

So the field induced
around the contour
is concentrated at the gap.

We go to a higher F stop
to protect the camera.

The integral of the
electric field intensity

is concentrated in a gap region
that is initially relatively

insulating, so the
electric field intensity

between the almost
touching wires
is enough to produce a spark.

The conductivity of
this aluminum disk

is more than 10 million times
larger than for human flesh,

and there's no gap to
limit the induced current.

If we presume that the
coil links the aluminum

disk with the same magnetic
flux as it does the hand,

the laws of Faraday
and Ohm would

say that the current density
should be more than 10
million times larger.

The conductivity of the
disk is 3.5 times 10

to the seventh siemens per
meter, rather than about 1,
as it was for the hand.

However, the current
induced in the disk

is so large that it produces
the field of its own

that limits the flux
actually linked by the disk.

The current induced in
the disk is so large

that it produces
a field of its own

that limits the flux
actually linked by the disk.

This induced magnetic
field tends to buck out
the field from the coil.

To see this, let's again
use Ampere's integral law

to estimate the magnetic
field intensity.

This time is the field
associated with a current that
is induced in the disk.

The result is the same
as it was for the coil,

except that, now, that
current is in the disk.

This current is roughly
the current density

times the average
cross-sectional area
of the disk.

The average radius, a, times
the disk thickness, delta.

Provided this
induced field is not

too large compared to
that from the coil,

we've already approximated
this current density.

So we can now evaluate the
ratio of the field associated

with the disk current to that
imposed by the coil current.

With the time rate
of change taken

as being roughly the angular
frequency times the peak

imposed field
intensity, this ratio

is within 4 pi of the
product of the angular

frequency and the
magnetic diffusion time.

This time is based
on the geometric mean

of the disk thickness
and its average radius.

If the frequency is high or
this magnetic diffusion time

is long, the current
induced in the disk

is large enough to prevent
much of the magnetic flux

from the coil penetrating
through its surface.

In the limit where
omega tau m is large,

the disk acts as the secondary
of an ideal transformer.

If the coil current
is like this,
it's induced field is upward.

The current in the disk
then responds so as
to buck out this flux.

So the disk current is
in the opposite direction
of the coil current.

Is the product of the frequency
and the magnetic diffusion

time for the aluminum
disk large enough

that it does tend to buck
out the imposed field?
First, let's evaluate tau m.
The thickness is 2 millimeters.

The average radius
is 7 centimeters.

And the conductivity of
aluminum is 3.5 times

10 to the seventh
siemens per meter.
So tau m is 6 milliseconds.

The ratio of H induced to H
imposed, omega tau m over 4 pi,
is about 12.

With the aluminum
disk, we are, indeed,

in the range where the disk
current produces a field that
bucks out the coil current.

According to our
approximate analysis,

the net field should tend to
be shielded out of the disk
by its own current.

The net field tends to be
tangential to the disk.

One result is a net
upward force on the disk.

This force is the result
of a force density,
J crossed with B--
J crossed with B.

The force can be
used to shape metals.

Here, the upward force
is evident in the shaping

of the outer edge
of a foil disk.

For this experiment, we
used three times as much
capacitance.

If the force can be
used to shape the metal,

it can also be used
to launch the disk.

If we leave the
disk alone, will it

lift off after the
button is pushed?

It's tempting to take an
experimental approach,

but it's more fun to
first see what we predict.

The net force on the disk is
the force density, J cross B,
integrated over the disk volume.

Essentially, this is the
surface current density

in the disk times
the magnetic flux

density in the gap
multiplied by the disk area.

The 1/2 accounts for
the variation of B
through the disk.

Because omega tau m
is large, the disk

tends to act as a nearly
perfect conductor.

Current in the disk is then
essentially equal to the field
intensity in the gap.

So this force is proportional
to the force per unit area--

1/2 mu 0 H squared times
the area of the disk.

The additional 1/2 is because
it is the time average
of the square that is affected.

To evaluate this force, we
guess that the field intensity

in the gap is, perhaps, 2 times
that caused by the coil alone.

Then the force peaks
at about 625 newtons.

The disk weighs about 80 grams
so that the force of gravity
is a little less than 1 newton.

The magnetic force is
about 800 times greater

than that due to gravity,
so we expect liftoff.

But the force only acts
for about a millisecond.

With what velocity
will it leave the coil?

With aerodynamic drag
ignored, Newton's law

states that this force
is equal to the mass M

of the disk times its
acceleration, the rate
of change of its velocity.

Here, the force is
represented by an impulse

having a duration T and
a magnitude, f sub 0,
equal to that just calculated.

Integration of this expression
from just before the button

is pushed when the
disk is at rest

to just after shows that the
initial velocity is this force

impulse divided by
the mass of the disk.

For our numbers, this
velocity is 8 meters

per second for about
18 miles per hour,
a good velocity for a bicycle.

Perhaps, we should estimate
how high the disk will
go before we push the button.

If the disk hurts the ceiling,
one of us might get fired.

The initial kinetic
energy of the disk

will be converted
to potential form

when it reaches its
maximum height, h.

g is the gravitational
acceleration.

We predict a height
of 3 meters, which

is sufficiently small that we
can perhaps responsibly push
the button.
I'm Meltzer.
And as you know, that's Zahn.

We brought along
an illuminary here
to push that button, finally.

This is Professor Doc
Edgerton, and it's his machine.

What we've done, of course,
is to show you this disk.

And now, if, Doc, you'd
turn on your machine.
HAROLD EDGERTON: Ready?
Here we go.

PROFESSOR: I'm going
to step out of this.

HAROLD EDGERTON: I'll
turn on the main power,
let it come up to charge.
Whooey!
Want to do it again?

PROFESSOR: Do you have
a favorite one there?

HAROLD EDGERTON: Well,
everyone's different.
Let's try this one.
What do you say?
Power it.
A little different ring to it.

PROFESSOR: Now, as
I understand it,

this thing's got more
capacitors in it.

Maybe we could get Zahn to
put a little more in there?

HAROLD EDGERTON: Yeah, you like
that to go a little higher?
Sure.

PROFESSOR: One of the reasons
I brought this man along

is that, in fact, he mainly
paid for this building.

So you see, we don't care too
much if we hurt that ceiling.

HAROLD EDGERTON: It'd be
nice to have an imprint
up there, wouldn't it?
PROFESSOR: Right.
With you here, I can say that.

HAROLD EDGERTON: OK, let's
see what happens this time.

Well, you got three
capacitors on instead of one.
It should go a little higher.
[DINGS]
Whooey!
[LAUGHTER]
Missed me.

PROFESSOR: Might
try our favorite?

HAROLD EDGERTON: Yeah,
let's try that one.

Hey, knocked a hole
in the ceiling.
[LAUGHTER]

PROFESSOR: And I can
see you enjoy that.

All right, thank
you very much, sir.

Actually, you're
getting the impression
this is all just fun and games.

If you look inside this box,
you'll find a number on it--

And circa sometime
like that, this man

was busy sounding the bottom
of the ocean with this device.

In fact, a few minutes ago, he
showed me a book that's out.
It's what?

Sonar Images by
Harold E. Edgerton.

And we were just
picking out something

in here that might
give you an idea

of the kind of serious
business that a boomer

like this or other sonar
devices can carry out.

Maybe, Doc, you could just
try and explain this to us.
HAROLD EDGERTON: It's a sonar.
This is a service to the ocean.

And then the sound goes down
and reflects off the bottom.
This is the bottom of the ocean.

And with these powerful sources
where you get enough energy,

it'll go through and gives
you sub bottoms down below

that are of tremendous
interest to the geologists.

They all want to know where
these sub bottoms are.

PROFESSOR: And as I understand
it, if we a big enough disk,

we make a low enough
frequency energy

that it does penetrate
that substrate.
HAROLD EDGERTON: Yep.

PROFESSOR: So you gave me a
little bigger disk here, huh?
HAROLD EDGERTON: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: Let me
get it out for us.

HAROLD EDGERTON: And I think
you realize, Jim, this--

PROFESSOR: Now,
there's a disk, huh?

HAROLD EDGERTON: Yeah,
this coil isn't so biggest.
PROFESSOR: No.

HAROLD EDGERTON: The coil
would be as big as this,

and we'd have maybe 10 times
as many capacitors on it.
PROFESSOR: [LAUGHS] Yes.
HAROLD EDGERTON: What do we got?
A small one on there now?

PROFESSOR: I was
trying to get him

to bring us over a disk that has
pits in it from the cavitation.

Unfortunately,
he's thrown it out.

HAROLD EDGERTON: Are
we going to hit it
with that maximum capacity?

PROFESSOR: Yeah, well,
he's got them all in.

HAROLD EDGERTON: All right,
back off a little bit.

I don't think
it'll go very high.
PROFESSOR: I'll back off.

HAROLD EDGERTON:
It'll make a noise.
I think it'll make a noise.
PROFESSOR: That's the point.
HAROLD EDGERTON: You ready?
Go.

PROFESSOR: That's
worth trying again.
HAROLD EDGERTON: Yeah.
[DINGS]
It jumps up about a 1/2 inch.

If you put enough energy, you
can throw the thing clear over.

PROFESSOR: Doc, thank you
very much for being here.
HAROLD EDGERTON: Thank you.
Thank you.
It's still ringing.
PROFESSOR: Hmm.
